The brightest member of the Alpha Persei Moving Group (Melotte 20), a sparse open cluster of about 100 stars moving together through space. At magnitude 1.80, it's the 35th brightest star in the sky. About 5,000 times more luminous than the Sun.

stars.name: Algol
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'ra's al-ghul' meaning 'head of the demon'it represents Medusa's severed head held by Perseus. Called the 'Demon Star' because it visibly winks every 2.87 days when the dimmer companion eclipses the brighter primary. Ancient cultures noticed its variability; it may be the 'Rosh ha Satan' mentioned in Hebrew texts. The first known eclipsing binary, explained by John Goodricke in 1783.

stars.name: Atik
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-'atiq' meaning 'the shoulder.' A close binary where both components are hot blue stars orbiting every 4.4 days. Referenced in the TV show Futurama as the home of Lrrr's species. About 25,000 times more luminous than the Sun, radiating fiercely in ultraviolet.

stars.name: Menkib
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'mankib al-thurayya' meaning 'shoulder of the Pleiades.' One of the hottest stars visible to the naked eye with a surface temperature of about 37,000Ksix times hotter than the Sun. Emits most of its radiation in far ultraviolet. Surrounded by a faint reflection nebula (NGC 1435) visible in long-exposure photographs.

stars.name: Alpheratz
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'surrat al-faras' meaning 'navel of the mare'it was shared with Pegasus as Delta Pegasi until constellation boundaries were finalized in 1930. Now forms one corner of the Great Square of Pegasus while belonging to Andromeda. A chemically peculiar star with overabundances of mercury and manganese created by slow diffusion in its stable atmosphere.

stars.name: Mirach
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-maraqq' meaning 'the loins' or 'the girdle.' A useful signpost for finding the Andromeda Galaxydraw a line from Mirach through Mu Andromedae and continue the same distance. About 1,900 times more luminous than the Sun. NGC 404, a dwarf lenticular galaxy nicknamed 'Mirach's Ghost,' appears just 7 arcminutes away.

stars.name: Almach
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-'anaq al-ard' meaning 'the caracal' (a wild cat). One of the finest double stars for small telescopes: the golden primary and blue-green secondary contrast beautifully, separated by 10 arcseconds. The secondary is itself a close triple. William Herschel praised it as one of the most beautiful objects in the sky.

stars.name: Adhil
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-dhayl' meaning 'the train' or 'train of a garment'part of the princess's trailing robe. A relatively faint star that marks the lower part of Andromeda's figure. About 100 times more luminous than the Sun, having evolved off the main sequence.

stars.name: Mothallah
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-muthallath' meaning 'the triangle.' The Greeks called this constellation Deltoton for its resemblance to their letter delta (). Aratus wrote that it marked the Nile River delta, while others associated it with the triangular island of Sicily, called Trinacria. Despite being the alpha star, it's actually fainter than Betalikely because Bayer was working from inaccurate charts. The system is a spectroscopic binary with two F-type giants orbiting each other every 1.74 days.

stars.name: Deltotum
stars.mythology: Named for the Greek letter Delta which the constellation resembles. Actually the brightest star in Triangulum despite being designated Beta. This white giant has evolved off the main sequence and is about 80 times more luminous than the Sun. Triangulum hosts M33, the Triangulum Galaxythe third largest member of our Local Group and the most distant object visible to the naked eye in good conditions at 2.7 million light-years.

stars.name: Gamma Trianguli
stars.mythology: Completes the famous triangle asterism with Alpha and Beta. The 'nn' in its spectral classification indicates it's a very rapid rotatorspinning at over 250 km/s at its equator, completing a rotation in less than 12 hours. This extreme rotation makes the star distinctly oblate, bulging at its equator. The constellation was one of the original 48 cataloged by Ptolemy, representing various triangular objects from mythology and geography.

stars.name: Beta Camelopardalis
stars.mythology: Brightest star in Camelopardalis, the Giraffea constellation invented in 1612 by Petrus Plancius to fill a dim region between Perseus and Polaris. The name means 'camel-leopard,' the ancient Greek term for a giraffe (which they thought combined a camel's body with leopard spots). Despite being the brightest star here, it has no traditional name because this area was historically considered empty sky. At 870 light-years, this yellow supergiant is about 1,600 times more luminous than the Sun.

stars.name: CS Camelopardalis
stars.mythology: A luminous blue supergiant over 3,000 light-years away, making it one of the most intrinsically bright stars visible to the naked eye in this region. It's a slowly pulsating B-type star with subtle brightness variations over several days. Camelopardalis represents the biblical camel that carried Rebecca to Isaac, according to Planciusone of several biblically-themed constellations he created. The constellation contains the asteroid Kamo'oalewa's predicted origin siteit may be a fragment blasted off the Moon.

stars.name: Alpha Camelopardalis
stars.mythology: A spectacular runaway star hurtling through space at roughly 60 km/s relative to its surroundings. This blue supergiant was likely ejected from its birthplace by a supernova explosion of a companion or by gravitational interactions in a dense cluster. It creates a visible bow shock as its stellar wind collides with the interstellar mediumlike the wake of a ship. At about 6,000 light-years distant and magnitude 4.29, it's intrinsically about 500,000 times more luminous than the Sun, making it one of the most luminous stars known.

stars.name: Alpha Lacertae
stars.mythology: Brightest star in Lacerta, the Lizarda small, dim constellation created by Johannes Hevelius in 1687. Hevelius placed it to fill the space between Cygnus and Andromeda. Despite the constellation's obscurity, it contains the prototype BL Lacertae objectan active galactic nucleus that defines an entire class of blazars. Alpha Lacertae itself is an ordinary white main-sequence star about twice the Sun's mass, notable mainly for its rapid rotation at about 128 km/s.

stars.name: 1 Lacertae
stars.mythology: An orange giant designated by its Flamsteed number rather than a Greek lettercommon in fainter constellations. The star has exhausted the hydrogen in its core and expanded to about 45 times the Sun's radius. 1 Lacertae lies within the Lacerta OB1 association, a group of young massive stars. Though the stars we see in Lacerta are unremarkable, the constellation is home to BL Lacertae, the prototype blazara supermassive black hole pointing its jet almost directly at Earth.

stars.name: Beta Lacertae
stars.mythology: A yellow giant that, like our Sun's distant future, has left the main sequence and begun its expansion toward becoming a red giant. At about 170 light-years, it's much closer than 1 Lacertae. The Lizard constellation lies along the Milky Way band but contains few notable deep-sky objectsits main claim to fame is BL Lacertae, discovered in 1929 but initially classified as an irregular variable star before its true extragalactic nature was recognized in 1968.

stars.name: Alpha Lyncis
stars.mythology: The sole named star in Lynx, a constellation Hevelius created in 1687 for the faint stars between Ursa Major and Auriga. He reportedly said you'd need the eyes of a lynx to see itthe wild cat was known for keen eyesight in European folklore. This orange giant is about 110 times more luminous than the Sun and has swelled to 55 times solar radius. Though dim, Lynx contains several interesting objects including NGC 2419, a remote globular cluster nicknamed the 'Intergalactic Wanderer.'

stars.name: 38 Lyncis
stars.mythology: A beautiful double star visible in small telescopes, with components of magnitudes 3.9 and 6.1 separated by about 2.7 arcseconds. First cataloged by William Herschel in 1782, who noted their striking color contrast. The system served as a test of telescope quality for early observersresolving it requires good optics. The pair are actually physically related, orbiting their common center of mass, making this a true binary system rather than an optical double.

stars.name: Alsciaukat
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-shaukah' meaning 'the thorn'a name transferred from older Arabic star catalogs where this region was part of different constellation figures. Though the Lynx is a modern Western invention, the star names in this area preserve fragments of Arabic astronomical tradition. This orange giant has evolved off the main sequence and expanded to about 40 times the Sun's radius. It's classified as a slow irregular variable, showing subtle brightness fluctuations.

stars.name: Adhara
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-'adhara' meaning 'the virgins'originally one of several stars forming this Arabic asterism. The 22nd brightest star in the night sky and the brightest source of extreme ultraviolet radiation in the sky. About 4.7 million years ago, Adhara was the brightest star visible from Earth at magnitude -3.99 (nearly rivaling Venus) when it was only 34 light-years away. It's currently pumping out about 38,000 times the Sun's luminosity and will eventually explode as a supernova.

stars.name: Wezen
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-wazn' meaning 'the weight'perhaps because it rises with difficulty on the horizon, seeming to carry a heavy burden. At about 1,800 light-years, Wezen is extraordinarily luminousroughly 50,000 times the Sun's output. It's a supergiant that has exhausted its core hydrogen and is now in the brief stage before its core begins fusing heavier elements. Within a few million years, it will explode as a supernova, potentially outshining the full Moon.

stars.name: Mirzam
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-murzim' meaning 'the announcer' or 'the herald'it rises just before Sirius, announcing the arrival of the brightest star. Mirzam is the prototype of a class of pulsating stars (Beta Cephei variables) that oscillate with periods of a few hours. Its brightness varies by only 0.04 magnitudes over about 6 hours as the star physically expands and contracts. This pulsation makes it valuable for studying stellar interiors.

stars.name: Aludra
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-'adhraa' meaning 'the maiden' or 'the virgin'part of the same Arabic asterism that gave Adhara its name. At about 2,000 light-years distant, Aludra is one of the most luminous stars visible to the naked eye, radiating over 100,000 times the Sun's energy. It's an Alpha Cygni variable, showing irregular brightness fluctuations due to pulsations in its outer layers. This massive star, about 20 solar masses, will end its life as a supernova in a few million years.

stars.name: Procyon
stars.mythology: From Greek 'prokyon' meaning 'before the dog'it rises before Sirius, the Dog Star, announcing its arrival. The eighth brightest star in the night sky, Procyon is one of our nearest stellar neighbors. It has a white dwarf companion, Procyon B, discovered in 1896the star has already exhausted its fuel and collapsed. Procyon A itself is leaving the main sequence and beginning to expand. In Hindu astronomy, it was Mrigavyadha, the deer hunter, with the Milky Way as his arrow.

stars.name: Gomeisa
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-ghumaisa' meaning 'the bleary-eyed one' or 'the weeping one'paired with Sirius in the Arabic asterism of the two sisters, one with clear eyes (Sirius) and one with weeping eyes (Gomeisa). The 'e' in its spectral type indicates it's a Be star with a gaseous disk around its equator, created by its rapid rotation at about 250 km/s. Material flung off by centrifugal force creates emission lines in its spectrum.

stars.name: Beta Monocerotis
stars.mythology: William Herschel called this 'one of the most beautiful sights in the heavens'three nearly identical blue-white stars in a curved arc, visible in small telescopes. All three are B3 main-sequence stars of similar brightness, making them appear as a delicate celestial necklace. Monoceros, the Unicorn, was created in the early 17th century to fill the dark space between Orion and Canis Major. The constellation lies along the winter Milky Way and hosts the Rosette Nebula and Cone Nebula.

stars.name: Alpha Monocerotis
stars.mythology: Despite being the alpha star of Monoceros, it's fainter than Betaa quirk of Bayer's original designations. This orange giant has about 15 times the Sun's radius and 50 times its luminosity. The Unicorn constellation is relatively modern, but the area was mentioned by ancient astronomers as a region of scattered stars. The constellation hosts V838 Monocerotis, which briefly became one of the brightest stars in the galaxy in 2002 during a dramatic outburst that astronomers still don't fully understand.

stars.name: Plaskett's Star
stars.mythology: Named for Canadian astronomer John Plaskett, who discovered in 1922 that this faint star was actually two massive O-type supergiants orbiting each other every 14.4 days. At the time, it was the most massive binary known, with components of about 50 and 47 solar masses. The stars are so close they likely exchange mass between them. Located about 6,600 light-years away in the outer Milky Way, both components will explode as supernovae within a few million years.

stars.name: Arneb
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-arnab' meaning 'the hare.' Lepus lies at Orion's feet, representing the hunter's quarry. In Egyptian mythology, Osiris was sometimes depicted as a hare. At about 2,200 light-years distant, Arneb is enormously luminous14,000 times the Sun's outputmaking it one of the most intrinsically bright stars visible to the naked eye. It's a supergiant in a brief evolutionary stage, having exhausted its core hydrogen and now burning helium, destined for eventual supernova.

stars.name: Nihal
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'nihl' meaning 'camels quenching their thirst'part of a larger Arabic asterism of camels drinking. Nihal is actually a double star, with a faint companion about 2.5 arcminutes away visible in binoculars. The primary is a yellow giant about 16 times the Sun's diameter. In the mythology of Orion, the Hare runs before the hunter while his two dogs (Canis Major and Minor) pursue. Some ancient Greek accounts say the hare was placed in the sky for producing too many offspring on the island of Leros.

stars.name: Phact
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-fakhita' meaning 'the ring dove.' Columba represents Noah's dove from the biblical flood narrativethe bird that returned with an olive branch, signaling land. The constellation was created by Petrus Plancius around 1592 from stars previously considered part of Canis Major. Phact is a Be star, rotating so rapidly (about 195 km/s) that it throws off material into a circumstellar disk. Its spectrum shows telltale emission lines from this disk.

stars.name: Wazn
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-wazn' meaning 'the weight'the same word that gives Wezen its name, probably indicating stars that appeared to rise with difficulty. At 87 light-years, Wazn is much closer than most stars in Columba. This orange giant has expanded to about 12 times the Sun's radius as it evolved off the main sequence. The dove constellation lies south of Canis Major and is best seen from the Southern Hemisphere, where it climbs higher in the sky.

stars.name: Ghusn al Zaitun
stars.mythology: Arabic for 'olive branch'directly referencing the biblical story of Noah's dove returning with proof that the flood waters had receded. This is one of the most literally named stars in the sky, its designation directly connecting to the constellation's mythology. The orange giant marks the dove's beak or head in some depictions. Columba is one of several biblical constellations introduced in the late 16th century by navigators charting southern skies.

stars.name: Naos
stars.mythology: From Greek 'naos' meaning 'ship'Puppis is the stern of the great ship Argo. Naos is one of the hottest and most luminous stars visible to the naked eye, with a surface temperature of 42,000 K and luminosity over 800,000 times the Sun. It's a runaway star ejected from a binary system when its companion exploded as a supernova. Its powerful stellar wind loses a mass equivalent to Earth every year. The star is moving through space at about 60 km/s, creating a bow shock as it plows through the interstellar medium.

stars.name: Pi Puppis
stars.mythology: Part of the ancient constellation Argo Navisthe ship that carried Jason and the Argonauts to find the Golden Fleece. When Nicolas Louis de Lacaille divided Argo into Puppis (stern), Vela (sails), and Carina (keel) in 1763, he kept the original Greek letter designations, which is why Puppis has no Alpha or Beta star. Pi Puppis has swelled to about 290 times the Sun's radius and shines with the light of 20,000 Suns.

stars.name: Rho Puppis
stars.mythology: The brightest Delta Scuti variable star in the sky, pulsating with multiple periods between 1 and 5 hours. At only 63 light-years distant, it's relatively nearby. Its surface shows chemical peculiaritiesenhanced metals like iron and bariumthat have risen to the surface during its evolution. The star's pulsations create subtle brightness variations useful for asteroseismology, the study of stellar interiors through their oscillations.

stars.name: Regor
stars.mythology: The name is 'Roger' spelled backwardan astronaut joke naming the star after Apollo 1 astronaut Roger Chaffee, who died in the 1967 launchpad fire. The most luminous Wolf-Rayet star visible to the naked eye, it's actually a complex multiple system. The Wolf-Rayet component has lost its outer hydrogen layers and exposes its helium-burning core, creating an intense stellar wind that carries away a solar mass every 100,000 years. Together with Canopus and other bright stars, it forms the False Cross asterism.

stars.name: Suhail al Muhlif
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'suhail' (a word possibly meaning 'smooth' or 'level') plus 'al-muhlif' ('the one by which one swears'). The rising of Suhail marked important calendar events for desert peoples. This orange supergiant is about 11,000 times more luminous than the Sun and has expanded to nearly 210 solar radii. It's an irregular variable star, showing unpredictable brightness fluctuations as its outer atmosphere pulses and churns.

stars.name: Kappa Velorum
stars.mythology: Also known as Markeb (from Arabic 'al-markab' meaning 'something to ride'referring to the ship). Part of the False Cross asterism that can confuse Southern Hemisphere navigators looking for the true Southern Cross. The system is a spectroscopic binary with two very similar B-type stars orbiting each other every 116 days. They're so close they likely influence each other's evolution through tidal effects.

stars.name: Delta Velorum
stars.mythology: Also called Alsephina, from Arabic 'al-safinah' meaning 'the ship.' Forms the northwestern corner of the False Cross asterism. The bright star is actually a multiple system, with the main component being an eclipsing binary where two A-type stars orbit each other every 45 days, causing regular dips in brightness. At only 80 light-years, it's the closest of Vela's bright stars. The False Cross has led many navigators astray when trying to identify the true Southern Cross.

stars.name: Canopus
stars.mythology: Named for the pilot of King Menelaus's ship in the Trojan War, who died in Egyptthe city of Canopus was built at his burial site. The second brightest star in the night sky after Sirius, and vastly more luminous intrinsicallyabout 10,700 times the Sun's output. For millennia, Canopus was used for celestial navigation by Polynesian and Arab sailors. Its brightness and position make it ideal for spacecraft navigation; many interplanetary missions use Canopus as a reference star for attitude control.

stars.name: Miaplacidus
stars.mythology: A hybrid name combining Arabic 'miyah' (waters) and Latin 'placidus' (calm)hence 'placid waters.' The second brightest star in Carina marks the ship's keel. At 111 light-years, it's a relatively nearby subgiant star that has begun evolving off the main sequence. It's about 3 solar masses and 288 times the Sun's luminosity. When Argo Navis was split into three constellations, Carina received the alpha and beta designations, making it the most prominent section of the ancient ship.

stars.name: Avior
stars.mythology: One of the few bright stars without an ancient name. During World War II, Her Majesty's Nautical Almanac Office needed names for navigation stars, and 'Avior' was coined by the Royal Air Forcepossibly derived from a combination of letters deemed euphonious. The star is actually a binary system with an orange giant and a hot blue companion orbiting each other. The contrasting spectral types make it useful for studying binary evolution.

stars.name: Capella
stars.mythology: Latin for 'little goat'representing the goat Amalthea that suckled the infant Zeus. The sixth brightest star in the night sky is actually four stars: two giant G-type stars orbiting each other every 104 days, plus a pair of faint red dwarfs. The main components are evolving giants, each about 12 solar radii. Capella was the brightest star in the sky about 210,000 years ago and will reclaim this title in about 220,000 years as stellar motions change our view. The nearby 'Kids' (Eta and Zeta Aurigae) represent the goat's offspring.

stars.name: Menkalinan
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'mankib dhi'l-'inan' meaning 'the shoulder of the rein-holder'Auriga is depicted as a charioteer holding reins. Menkalinan is an eclipsing binary where two nearly identical A-type stars orbit each other every 3.96 days. The eclipses cause a 0.1-magnitude brightness drop, first detected in 1890. The system is particularly useful for stellar physics because both components can be well-characterized, providing stringent tests of stellar models.

stars.name: Almaaz
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-ma'z' meaning 'the billy goat'one of the Kids. One of the longest-period and most enigmatic eclipsing binaries known. Every 27.1 years, an eclipse lasting about 2 years occurs when something passes in front of the F-type supergiant. For decades, astronomers debated what caused these eclipsesthe companion appears to be a B-type star surrounded by an enormous disk of dark material, perhaps a remnant protoplanetary disk or debris from past mass transfer. The 2009-2011 eclipse was studied extensively by professional and citizen science campaigns.

stars.name: Eta Aurigae
stars.mythology: Another of the Kids (Haedi) in Auriga's goat asterism. At 3.18 magnitude, it's the faintest of the three Kids. This is a relatively unremarkable B-type main sequence starabout 5 solar masses and 700 times the Sun's luminosity. It rotates rapidly at about 95 km/s. The three Kids (Epsilon, Zeta, and Eta) form a small triangle that has been recognized since antiquity as the offspring of the she-goat Capella.

stars.name: Zeta Aurigae
stars.mythology: Also called Haedus I or Sadatoni (from Arabic 'the second arm'). Like Epsilon Aurigae, this is an eclipsing binary with a very different pair of stars: an orange supergiant and a hot blue main-sequence companion. Every 972 days, the blue star passes behind the supergiant's extended atmosphere, and spectroscopic observations during ingress and egress probe the structure of the giant's outer layersa technique called atmospheric eclipses. This makes Zeta Aurigae a key star for understanding stellar atmospheres.

stars.name: Achernar
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'akhir al-nahr' meaning 'the end of the river'marking where the celestial River Eridanus meets the southern horizon from Mediterranean latitudes. The ninth brightest star in the sky and the flattest known star: spinning so rapidly (about 250 km/s at its equator) that its equatorial diameter is about 50% greater than its polar diameter. This extreme oblateness was first measured using interferometry. The 'p' in its spectral type indicates peculiar chemical abundances.

stars.name: Acamar
stars.mythology: Also from Arabic 'akhir al-nahr'the same phrase as Achernar, because Acamar was once considered the river's end before precession brought Achernar into view from ancient Mediterranean civilizations. Acamar marked the river's terminus in Ptolemy's catalog. It's a beautiful double star, with components of magnitudes 3.2 and 4.3 separated by 8 arcsecondseasily split in small telescopes. The primary is an evolved giant while the secondary remains on the main sequence.

stars.name: Cursa
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-kursi' meaning 'the footstool' or 'chair'positioned near Orion's foot (Rigel). Cursa marks the beginning of the River Eridanus, which winds southward across the sky. This white giant has exhausted its core hydrogen and is evolving toward becoming a red giant. At 89 light-years, it's relatively nearby. The constellation Eridanus stretches over 60 degrees, making it the sixth largest constellation by area.

stars.name: Zaurak
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-zawraq' meaning 'the boat'part of an Arabic asterism distinct from the Greek river. This red giant has cooled to about 3,800 K and expanded to about 80 times the Sun's radius. It's classified as a suspected variable star with slight irregular brightness changes. Zaurak marks a bend in the meandering course of Eridanus, which the Greeks associated with the mythical river Eridanos, into which Phaethon fell after losing control of the sun chariot.

stars.name: Epsilon Eridani
stars.mythology: One of the closest Sun-like stars at only 10.5 light-yearsa key target for exoplanet searches and SETI. The star is younger than the Sun (about 400-800 million years) and more active, with prominent starspots and a strong stellar wind. It hosts at least one confirmed planet and is surrounded by an asteroid belt and outer debris disk. Epsilon Eridani was the first target of Project Ozma in 1960, humanity's first systematic search for extraterrestrial radio signals. In science fiction, it has been imagined as the home system of Vulcan (Star Trek) and Babylon 5.

stars.name: Altair
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-nasr al-ta'ir' meaning 'the flying eagle.' The 12th brightest star in the night sky and one of the closest visible stars. Altair rotates incredibly fastcompleting a rotation every 9 hours versus the Sun's 25 dayscausing it to bulge at its equator, confirmed by interferometric imaging. Along with Vega and Deneb, it forms the Summer Triangle. In the Chinese Qixi Festival, Altair represents the cowherd Niulang, separated from his love Zhinu (Vega) by the Milky Way, able to meet only once a year.

stars.name: Alshain
stars.mythology: From Persian 'shahin' meaning 'falcon' or 'royal falcon'a word that became associated with the eagle constellation through Arabic translation. Alshain is a yellow subgiant that has exhausted its core hydrogen and is expanding and cooling. At 44.7 light-years, it's relatively nearby. The star has a very faint red dwarf companion. In Chinese astronomy, Alshain and Tarazed were the sons of the cowherd (Altair).

stars.name: Tarazed
stars.mythology: From Persian 'shahin tarazed' meaning 'the beam of the scale'the full phrase described the three stars Altair, Alshain, and Tarazed as a scale or balance. This orange giant is about 2,500 times more luminous than the Sun, having evolved far off the main sequence. Its cooler temperature gives it a distinctly orange hue, contrasting beautifully with white Altair nearby. In Chinese mythology, Tarazed was one of Altair's sons, accompanying the cowherd across the sky.

stars.name: Arcturus
stars.mythology: From Greek 'arktos ouros' meaning 'guardian of the bear'it follows Ursa Major around the pole. The fourth brightest star in the night sky and the brightest in the northern celestial hemisphere. Arcturus is unusual: it belongs to the Milky Way's halo population, passing through the disk on an orbit that takes it far above and below the galactic plane. It's part of a stream of stars captured from a smaller galaxy. Arcturus powered the lights at the 1933 Chicago World's Fair40-year-old light from the 1893 fair was focused on photocells.

stars.name: Nekkar
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-baqqar' meaning 'the herdsman'the whole constellation represents a herdsman driving the bears around the pole. Despite its beta designation, Nekkar is only the fourth brightest star in Botes. In 1993, a gamma-ray burst (GRB 930131) was detected coming from Nekkar's general directionone of the early gamma-ray bursts that eventually proved to be cosmological in origin. The star itself is a mild barium star, showing enhanced abundances of heavy elements.

stars.name: Seginus
stars.mythology: The name likely derives from a corrupted form of the constellation's Latin name. Seginus is a Delta Scuti variable star, pulsating with multiple periods between 1 and 2 hoursits brightness varies by about 0.05 magnitudes. It's an evolved white giant about 3 times the Sun's mass. The Botes constellation has been interpreted variously as a herdsman, plowman, or bear-driver, and appears in some of the oldest surviving star catalogs.

stars.name: Izar
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-izar' meaning 'the girdle' or 'loincloth'marking the herdsman's waist. The 19th-century astronomer Wilhelm Struve called it 'Pulcherrima' (Latin for 'most beautiful') after observing it through his telescope. The system consists of an orange giant and a white main-sequence companion separated by 2.8 arcsecondstheir contrasting colors (gold and blue-green) make this one of the finest double stars in the sky for small telescopes.

stars.name: Muphrid
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'mufrad al-ramih' meaning 'the single one of the lancer'one of the few prominent stars in this part of the sky. Muphrid is a close stellar neighbor at only 37 light-years and is remarkably similar to our Sun's likely future: a star that has finished fusing hydrogen in its core and is beginning to expand. At 9 times solar luminosity, it's well on its way to becoming a red giant. It's also one of Arcturus's closest stellar neighbors, the two appearing just 3.3 degrees apart in our sky.

stars.name: Alphecca
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-fakkah' meaning 'the broken' or 'the broken one'referring to the semicircular crown shape. Also known as Gemma (the jewel in the crown). In Greek mythology, the crown belonged to Ariadne, given to her by Dionysus and placed in the sky after her death. Alphecca is an eclipsing binary similar to Algol, with a hot A-type star eclipsed by a cooler G-type companion every 17.4 days, causing a 0.1-magnitude brightness dip.

stars.name: Nusakan
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-nasaqan' meaning 'the two lines' or 'the two series'possibly referring to rows of stars. This is a magnetic Ap starone of the so-called 'peculiar A stars' with unusually strong magnetic fields that cause chemical elements to collect in patches on the stellar surface. As the star rotates every 18.5 days, these patches move in and out of view, causing subtle brightness variations. It's the prototype of one subclass of these chemically peculiar variables.

stars.name: Sualocin
stars.mythology: One of astronomy's most audacious pranks: 'Sualocin' is 'Nicolaus' spelled backward, for Niccol Cacciatore (Latinized as Nicolaus Venator), assistant to astronomer Giuseppe Piazzi. Cacciatore slipped the name into the 1814 Palermo Star Catalogue, and no one noticed for years. By the time the joke was discovered, the name had been widely adopted. The star is a spectroscopic binary with components orbiting every 17 days.

stars.name: Rotanev
stars.mythology: 'Rotanev' is 'Venator' spelled backwardthe second half of Cacciatore's prank on astronomy. 'Venator' means 'hunter' in Latin, the translation of his Italian surname. These are the only two star names derived from a living person who wasn't royalty. The star itself is a close binary with two nearly identical F-type subgiants orbiting each other every 27 yearsa beautiful system where both stars have just begun evolving off the main sequence.

stars.name: Rasalhague
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'ra's al-hawwa' meaning 'head of the serpent collector'Ophiuchus is depicted wrestling a giant snake. The brightest star in Ophiuchus is a fast-spinning white giant at only 47 light-years. Like Altair, its rapid rotation (240 km/s at the equator) makes it distinctly oblate. Despite Ophiuchus being one of the largest constellations, the Sun passes through it from November 29 to December 18yet it's not included in the traditional zodiac.

stars.name: Sabik
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'sabiq' meaning 'the preceding one'indicating its position relative to other stars in the figure. Sabik is a close double star with two white A-type stars separated by only 0.5 arcseconds, orbiting each other every 88 years. The system is gradually separating and will be an easier double to split in coming decades. Despite being the eta star, it's the second brightest in Ophiuchus after Rasalhague.

stars.name: Yed Prior
stars.mythology: A hybrid name: 'Yed' from Arabic 'al-yad' (the hand) and 'Prior' from Latin (before or preceding). It marks one of Ophiuchus's hands grasping the serpent. Together with nearby Yed Posterior (Epsilon Ophiuchi), it forms a naked-eye pair representing the serpent-handler's left hand. This cool red giant has a surface temperature of only 3,800 K and has expanded to about 59 times the Sun's radius.

stars.name: Barnard's Star
stars.mythology: Named for E.E. Barnard who discovered in 1916 that it has the highest proper motion of any starmoving 10.3 arcseconds per year across our sky (a full Moon width every 180 years). At only 6 light-years, it's the closest star visible from the Northern Hemisphere and the fourth closest star system overall. Though invisible to the naked eye, it has been a perennial target for exoplanet searches. In 2018, a possible super-Earth was announced, though its existence remains debated. Barnard's Star is ancient10-12 billion years old.

stars.name: Gamma Sagittae
stars.mythology: The brightest star in Sagitta, the Arrowone of the smallest constellations but one of the 48 listed by Ptolemy. Various myths identify it as the arrow that killed the eagle Aquila, Cupid's arrow, or the arrow of Apollo. This cool red giant marks the middle of the arrow's shaft. Sagitta lies in a rich part of the Milky Way and contains M71, an unusual globular cluster that some once classified as an open cluster due to its loose structure.

stars.name: Delta Sagittae
stars.mythology: Marks the tip of the celestial arrow. This system contains a remarkable pairing: a cool red giant and a hot blue companion. The components are separated enough to observe individually in medium telescopes. The fainter blue component is about 100 times more luminous than the Sun but appears dim next to the intrinsically brighter red giant. The dramatic color contrast makes this an interesting target for observers.

stars.name: Sham
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'sahm' meaning 'arrow'the name of the entire constellation applied to its alpha star, even though it's not the brightest. Sham marks the arrow's nock (the end that fits the bowstring). Despite its alpha designation, it's fainter than both Gamma and Delta Sagittae, a quirk of Bayer's original magnitude estimates. This yellow giant is about 340 times more luminous than the Sun.

stars.name: Unukalhai
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'unuq al-hayyah' meaning 'the neck of the serpent.' Serpens is uniquethe only constellation split into two parts (Serpens Caput, the head, and Serpens Cauda, the tail) by Ophiuchus, who holds the snake. Unukalhai marks the snake's neck. It's an orange giant about 38 times more luminous than the Sun. The entire snake-and-handler figure symbolizes Asclepius, the Greek god of medicine, represented today by the caduceus.

stars.name: Alya
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-alyah' meaning 'the fat tail of a sheep'an Arabic asterism that included this region. Alya lies in Serpens Cauda, the tail portion of the serpent. It's a beautiful double star with two nearly identical white components separated by 22 arcsecondseasily split in any telescope or even binoculars. Both stars are about twice the Sun's mass, and they orbit their common center of mass over a very long period.

stars.name: Alpha Scuti
stars.mythology: Brightest star in Scutum Sobiescii (Sobieski's Shield)a constellation created by Johannes Hevelius in 1684 to honor King Jan III Sobieski of Poland, who defended Vienna from the Ottoman siege in 1683. It's the only constellation named for a real historical figure that's still in use. This unremarkable orange giant happens to lie in one of the richest star fields in the sky, embedded in the Scutum Star Cloud of the Milky Way.

stars.name: UY Scuti
stars.mythology: One of the largest known stars by radiusestimates suggest it may be 1,700 solar radii or larger, though measuring such extreme stars is difficult. If placed at the Sun's position, its surface would extend beyond Jupiter's orbit, possibly reaching Saturn. This pulsating red supergiant varies between magnitudes 8.3 and 10.5 over about 740 days. At its estimated distance of nearly 10,000 light-years, it's extraordinarily luminousabout 340,000 times the Sun's output. It will eventually explode as a supernova.

stars.name: Delta Scuti
stars.mythology: The prototype of an important class of pulsating variable stars. Delta Scuti variables oscillate in multiple modes simultaneously with periods between 20 minutes and 8 hours, and the study of these oscillations (asteroseismology) reveals their internal structure. The star pulsates with at least 8 different periods between 1 and 5 hours. These variables have been critical for understanding stellar interiors and testing stellar evolution models, and thousands are now known throughout the galaxy.

stars.name: Anser
stars.mythology: Latin for 'goose'Hevelius originally named the constellation 'Vulpecula cum Ansere' (The Little Fox with the Goose) in 1687. The goose was eventually dropped from the name, but the brightest star retained the reference. This red giant of about 45 solar radii lies near the famous Dumbbell Nebula (M27), one of the brightest planetary nebulae in the sky. Vulpecula also contains the first pulsar ever discovered (PSR B1919+21, found in 1967).

stars.name: Kitalpha
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'qit'at al-faras' meaning 'a piece of the horse'Equuleus is the Little Horse, the second smallest constellation. Only the horse's head is depicted, and various myths identify it as Celeris (brother of Pegasus) or the foal Hippe. The star is a spectroscopic binary with a yellow giant and white main-sequence companion. Despite its tiny size, Equuleus was one of Ptolemy's original 48 constellations and has been recognized since antiquity.

stars.name: Kornephoros
stars.mythology: From Greek 'korunephoros' meaning 'club-bearer'one of Hercules's attributes was his massive wooden club. Surprisingly, this beta star is the brightest in Hercules, brighter than Alpha (Rasalgethi). This yellow giant is about 175 times more luminous than the Sun and has expanded to 17 solar radii. Hercules contains the great globular cluster M13, visible to the naked eye as a fuzzy star and containing several hundred thousand ancient stars.

stars.name: Rasalgethi
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'ra's al-jathi' meaning 'head of the kneeler'Hercules is depicted upside-down in the sky, kneeling with head pointed south. This semiregular variable red supergiant pulsates between magnitudes 2.7 and 4.0 over a roughly 90-day period. It has a yellow companion visible in telescopes, and the color contrast between the orange-red primary and greenish secondary is striking. Rasalgethi has expanded to about 300 solar radii and is shedding mass through a powerful stellar wind.

stars.name: Sarin
stars.mythology: The origin of this name is obscureit may be from an Arabic phrase meaning 'two things.' Sarin forms part of the Keystone asterism that marks Hercules's bodya distinctive quadrilateral of stars recognizable in the summer sky. The Keystone serves as a guide to finding M13, the great globular cluster, located along one of its sides. Sarin is a close binary with a 10-year orbital period.

stars.name: Enif
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'anf al-faras' meaning 'the nose of the horse'marking the flying horse's muzzle. The brightest star in Pegasus is a luminous orange supergiant about 5,000 times more luminous than the Sun. In 1972, Enif experienced a brief flare, brightening by nearly a full magnitude for a few minutesa rare event for a supergiant. It will eventually explode as a supernova, though not for several million years.

stars.name: Scheat
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'sa'q' meaning 'the shin' or 'leg'though it marks the horse's shoulder or upper leg. Scheat is a semiregular variable, fluctuating between magnitudes 2.31 and 2.74 over about 43 days. This cool red giant has a surface temperature of only 3,700 K and has swelled to about 95 times the Sun's radius. It forms one corner of the Great Square of Pegasus, the famous asterism that dominates the autumn sky.

stars.name: Markab
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'mankib al-faras' meaning 'the saddle of the horse' or simply 'markab' (something to ride). Forms the southwestern corner of the Great Square of Pegasus. Despite being the alpha star, Markab is actually the third brightest in the constellation after Enif and Scheat. It's a hot blue-white giant about 200 times more luminous than the Sun, notable for having a high rotation velocity that makes its absorption lines appear broadened in spectra.

stars.name: 51 Pegasi
stars.mythology: In 1995, Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz detected the first exoplanet orbiting a Sun-like star51 Pegasi b (nicknamed Bellerophon, then later officially named Dimidium). This discovery revolutionized astronomy and launched the exoplanet era. The planet is a 'hot Jupiter'a gas giant orbiting just 0.05 AU from its star every 4.2 days. Mayor and Queloz won the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics for this discovery. The star has since been officially named Helvetios (the Latin name for the Helvetii people of Switzerland).

stars.name: Mira
stars.mythology: Latin for 'wonderful' or 'astonishing'named by astronomer Johannes Hevelius in 1662 for its remarkable variability. Mira was the first variable star recognized (other than novae), its 332-day cycle discovered in 1596 by David Fabricius. At maximum, it's easily visible; at minimum, it requires a telescope. Mira is a dying red giant shedding mass in a stellar wind, leaving a 13-light-year-long tail of material behind it as it races through spacediscovered by GALEX in 2007. It has a white dwarf companion, Mira B.

stars.name: Diphda
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-difda' al-thani' meaning 'the second frog'the first frog was Fomalhaut. Arabs saw frogs near the celestial 'river' of the sky. Despite being Beta Ceti, it's the brightest star in the Sea Monster constellation. Diphda is a mild barium star, showing enhanced abundances of heavy elements likely acquired from a now-dead companion (now a white dwarf). It's currently the nearest giant star to our Sun that shows this chemical peculiarity.

stars.name: Tau Ceti
stars.mythology: At only 12 light-years away, Tau Ceti is one of the closest Sun-like stars and was the second target of Project Ozma, the first SETI search. It's a stable, quiet star slightly smaller and cooler than the Sun, surrounded by a massive debris disk ten times more substantial than our Kuiper Belt. Several planet candidates have been proposed. For decades, Tau Ceti has been a favorite setting for science fictionhome systems in many stories. Its similarity to our Sun makes it a compelling target for future interstellar exploration.

stars.name: Alphard
stars.mythology: From Arabic 'al-fard' meaning 'the solitary one'it's the only bright star in a vast, dim region of sky. Hydra, the water snake, is the largest of all 88 constellations, stretching over 100 degrees. Alphard represents the serpent's heart. In Greek mythology, Hydra is the multi-headed monster slain by Hercules, or the water snake that Apollo sent a crow to fetch water in. The orange giant is about 400 times more luminous than the Sun, with a distinct orange hue that earned it the nickname 'the backbone of the Serpent' in medieval Arabic.

stars.name: Gamma Hydrae
stars.mythology: Marks the point where Hydra's long body begins after its head. This yellow giant has exhausted its core hydrogen and evolved off the main sequence. Hydra's head is actually closer to the celestial equator, with the body stretching far to the south. The constellation takes several hours to rise completelyby the time the tail clears the eastern horizon, the head has already begun to set in the west. Despite being gamma, this star is the second brightest in the constellation.

stars.name: R Hydrae
stars.mythology: A Mira-type pulsating variable star that ranges from naked-eye visibility to requiring a telescope over its 389-day period. First recorded by Hevelius in 1662, it was one of the earliest variable stars discovered. The period has been steadily decreasing over the centuriesfrom about 500 days in 1700 to 389 days nowsuggesting ongoing changes in the star's internal structure. R Hydrae is a dying red giant losing mass in a stellar wind, surrounded by a dusty shell.

stars.name: Cor Caroli
stars.mythology: Latin for 'Heart of Charles'named by Edmond Halley to honor King Charles II of England, supposedly because the star shone especially bright on the eve of Charles's restoration to the throne in 1660. The primary is a chemically peculiar Ap starthe prototype of a class of variables called Alpha-2 Canum Venaticorum stars. Its magnetic field causes chemical elements to concentrate in patches, creating subtle brightness variations as it rotates. The constellation represents the hunting dogs of Botes.

greek.name: The Seven Sisters
greek.story: The Pleiades were the seven daughters of the Titan Atlas and the sea-nymph Pleione: Alcyone, Electra, Maia, Merope, Taygeta, Celaeno, and Sterope (Asterope). Pursued by the hunter Orion for seven years, they begged Zeus for rescue, and he transformed them into doves and then into stars. Atlas was condemned to hold up the sky, and his daughters can only watch him from above. Maia was the mother of Hermes by Zeus. Merope is the faintest because she hid in shame after marrying the mortal Sisyphus. Some say there were originally more sisters, or that one 'lost Pleiad' faded in grief.
greek.note: Only six stars are easily visible; the 'lost Pleiad' explains this

japanese.name: Subaru
japanese.story: The Japanese name for the Pleiades, meaning 'to gather together' or 'united.' The automobile company Subaru takes its name and star logo from this cluster. In Japanese folklore, the cluster was associated with unity and working together.
japanese.significance: Source of the Subaru car company name

australian_aboriginal.name: Kungkarungkara (Various)
australian_aboriginal.story: Many Aboriginal Australian groups have stories about the Pleiades, often as a group of women fleeing an unwanted pursuer (like the Greek Orion). In some stories, they are the Seven Sisters being chased by the man in Orion, and the Milky Way is dust kicked up in the chase.

lakota.name: Wicincala Sakowin (Seven Little Girls)
lakota.story: Seven sisters were playing on a rock when chased by a great bear. The rock grew into the sky to protect them, becoming Devils Tower. The sisters became the Pleiades, and the bear's claw marks are the striations on the tower.

cherokee.name: Ani'tsutsa (The Boys)
cherokee.story: Seven boys neglected their duties and danced instead. Their mothers threw corn cobs at them, and they danced higher and higher until they rose into the sky. One mother grabbed her son's foot, but he fell back to earth, and a pine tree grew where he fell.

hindu.name: Krittika
hindu.story: The Pleiades form the nakshatra Krittika, the wives of the Seven Sages (Big Dipper). They nursed the infant war god Kartikeya (Skanda), who is therefore called 'son of the Krittikas.' This nakshatra is ruled by Agni, the fire god.

chinese.name: Mao (Hairy Head)
chinese.story: The Pleiades form the lunar mansion Mao, associated with penalties, executions, and the head of the White Tiger. In ancient China, the heliacal rising of the Pleiades marked the beginning of the agricultural year.

mesopotamian.name: MUL.MUL (Star Cluster)
mesopotamian.story: The Babylonians called it simply 'the star cluster' and considered it extremely important for their calendar. The new year began when the Pleiades made their first appearance after being hidden in the Sun's glare.

mythology.note: See Ursa Major for detailed mythology
mythology.universality: This is perhaps the most universally recognized star pattern, known by different names across virtually all northern hemisphere cultures

mythology.name: Tears of Saint Lawrence
mythology.story: In Christian tradition, the Perseids are called the 'Tears of Saint Lawrence,' as they peak near his feast day (August 10). Lawrence was a deacon martyred in 258 CE. In Greek mythology, they might be associated with Perseus, as the meteors radiate from that constellation - perhaps representing the golden shower in which Zeus visited Danae, Perseus's mother.

The Leonids have produced some of the most spectacular meteor storms in history. The 1833 storm over North America (estimated 100,000 meteors/hour) was seen as an apocalyptic sign by many and spurred scientific study of meteors. Major storms occur roughly every 33 years when Earth passes through dense debris.

Unique among major meteor showers, the Geminids originate from an asteroid rather than a comet. The asteroid is named Phaethon after the Greek myth of the boy who drove the Sun's chariot. The meteors are the debris he scattered when he lost control and was struck down by Zeus's thunderbolt to prevent Earth from burning.

Along with the Orionids in October, the Eta Aquariids are produced by debris from Halley's Comet. Earth crosses Halley's orbit twice per year, encountering meteor streams each time. Halley's Comet has been observed since at least 240 BCE and was recorded in the Bayeux Tapestry (1066 CE).
